laws.summary: Vermont prohibits employers from asking applicants about wage or salary history and from relying on such information to determine compensation.
requirements: Employers may not inquire into an applicant’s wage or salary history
Employers may not seek wage history from current or former employers
Applicants may voluntarily disclose wage history without prompting
Employers may confirm wage history only if the applicant voluntarily discloses it
Retaliation for refusing to disclose wage history is prohibited
laws.notes: This is a strict statewide salary history ban.

laws.summary: Vermont requires covered employers to include compensation or a compensation range in job advertisements.
requirements: Employers must include the compensation or compensation range in job advertisements
Postings must be made in good faith
Applies to internal and external postings
Employers may not prohibit employees from discussing wages
Retaliation for wage discussion or pay inquiries is prohibited
laws.notes: Vermont is among the states that mandate pay ranges in job postings.

laws.summary: Vermont restricts non-compete agreements for low-wage employees and applies reasonableness standards for others.
requirements: Non-competes are prohibited for employees earning at or below the Vermont minimum wage
Non-competes must protect legitimate business interests
Must be reasonable in time, geographic scope, and job scope
Overly broad restrictions may be unenforceable
Courts scrutinize restrictive covenants closely
laws.notes: Vermont is relatively employee-protective regarding restrictive covenants.

laws.summary: Vermont restricts criminal history inquiries under its ban-the-box law and requires FCRA compliance for third-party background checks.
laws.statute_citation: 21 V.S.A. § 495j; Fair Credit Reporting Act (15 U.S.C. § 1681)
requirements: Employers generally may not inquire into criminal history on initial job applications
Criminal history inquiries may occur later in the hiring process
If using third-party background checks, written consent is required
Pre-adverse action notice must be provided with report and rights
Final adverse action notice must be provided if a negative decision is made
laws.notes: Vermont has a statewide ban-the-box law applicable to private employers.

laws.summary: Vermont mandates paid sick leave and protects various statutory leave rights.
requirements: Employees accrue at least 1 hour of paid sick leave per 52 hours worked
Employers must allow use of at least 40 hours of paid sick leave per year
Leave covers illness, preventive care, family care, and safe leave purposes
Employees must be allowed jury duty leave without retaliation
Offer letters must not conflict with statutory paid leave rights
laws.notes: Paid sick leave is mandatory for most Vermont employers.

laws.summary: Vermont legalizes recreational cannabis, but employment protections for off-duty use are limited.
requirements: Employers may maintain drug-free workplace policies
Employers may prohibit impairment during working hours
Employers may take action based on positive drug tests depending on policy
Policies must be applied consistently and in compliance with anti-discrimination laws
laws.notes: Unlike some states, Vermont does not provide broad statutory employment protections for cannabis use.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable in Vermont if consistent with contract law and federal arbitration principles.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; Vermont contract law
requirements: Agreement must be voluntary and clearly written
Must not be unconscionable
Must provide reasonable notice
Courts may invalidate unfair or one-sided clauses

laws.summary: Vermont follows the at-will employment doctrine, subject to statutory, contractual, and public policy exceptions.
requirements: Employment is presumed at-will unless contract specifies otherwise
Cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Cannot retaliate for protected activity
Public policy exceptions apply
Employee handbooks may create implied contractual obligations
laws.notes: Clear at-will language in offer letters is recommended.

laws.summary: Vermont law prohibits employment discrimination on a broad range of protected characteristics.
laws.statute_citation: 21 V.S.A. § 495 et seq. (Vermont Fair Employment Practices Act)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, religion, sex, gender identity, sexual orientation
Cannot discriminate based on age, disability, national origin, ancestry
Cannot discriminate based on marital status or domestic violence victim status
Harassment is prohibited
Retaliation for protected activity is prohibited
laws.notes: Vermont provides broader civil rights protections than federal law in several areas.

data_quality.sources: Vermont Statutes, Vermont Department of Labor, official state guidance
data_quality.coverage_completeness: comprehensive for offer-letter and hiring compliance

additional_notes.general_guidance: Vermont is employee-protective, with mandatory pay transparency, salary history bans, paid sick leave, and statewide ban-the-box protections. Offer letters and hiring practices must be carefully structured for compliance.
recent_developments: Ongoing enforcement of salary history ban
Continued enforcement of earned sick time law
